domain: Domain 5: Social & Cultural Bases of Behavior

questions.stem: An expert pianist performs a complex concerto significantly better during a live concert than during solo practice. According to Zajonc's drive theory of social facilitation, this improvement occurs because:

options.text: The audience provides normative social influence encouraging better performance
The audience increases arousal, which strengthens the dominant (well-practiced) response
Evaluation apprehension reduces the pianist's anxiety through social support
The diffusion of responsibility in the audience reduces performance pressure

questions.explanation: Zajonc's (1965) drive theory of social facilitation proposes that the presence of others increases physiological arousal, which strengthens the emission of the dominant response. For an expert pianist, the well-practiced concerto is the dominant response, so audience presence enhances performance. For a novice, the dominant response would be incorrect (errors), so audience presence would impair performance. This distinction between simple/well-learned tasks and complex/novel tasks is central to social facilitation theory.

questions.stem: In Milgram's baseline obedience experiment, approximately what percentage of participants administered the maximum 450-volt shock as instructed by the experimenter?
questions.explanation: In Milgram's (1963) baseline condition, where the participant and learner were in separate rooms and the experimenter gave instructions in person, 65% of participants obeyed to the maximum 450V level. All participants obeyed to at least 300V. This finding was shocking because prior surveys of psychiatrists, students, and laypeople had predicted that virtually no one would go to the maximum. The study demonstrated the powerful influence of authority figures on behavior.

questions.stem: A therapy group has been meeting for several weeks. Members are now openly disagreeing with each other, challenging the therapist's authority, and competing for influence within the group. According to Tuckman's model of group development, this group is most likely in which stage?

options.text: Forming
Storming
Norming
Performing

questions.explanation: According to Tuckman's (1965) model, the storming stage is characterized by conflict, resistance to group influence, power struggles, and disagreements. Members challenge each other and the leader as they negotiate roles and norms. This is a normal and necessary developmental stage. Understanding that conflict (storming) is expected helps group therapists avoid prematurely intervening to suppress disagreement, which could impede the group's progression to the norming and performing stages.

questions.stem: In Asch's conformity experiments, which modification most dramatically reduced the conformity rate?

options.text: Increasing the group size from 3 to 15 confederates
Allowing participants to write their answers privately
Having one confederate give the correct answer, breaking unanimity
Using more ambiguous stimuli for the line comparison task

questions.explanation: The single most dramatic reduction in conformity occurred when unanimity was broken by a single dissenter. Even if the dissenter gave a different wrong answer, conformity dropped significantly because the participant no longer faced a unanimous majority. Group size beyond 3-5 members had diminishing effects. Private responses reduced conformity somewhat but not as dramatically as breaking unanimity. More ambiguous stimuli actually increased conformity through informational social influence.

questions.stem: According to Moscovici's conversion theory, minority influence differs from majority influence primarily because minority influence:

options.text: Produces only public compliance without any private attitude change
Triggers deeper cognitive processing that can produce genuine private attitude change (conversion)
Requires the minority to hold a position more extreme than the majority
Only works when the minority has higher social status than the majority

questions.explanation: Moscovici's (1980) conversion theory proposes that majority influence operates through comparison (people conform publicly to fit in) producing compliance, while minority influence operates through validation (the minority's consistent position triggers deeper cognitive processing) producing conversion -- genuine private attitude change. The minority's consistent and confident position causes majority members to think more deeply about the issue. Importantly, minority influence often appears as indirect influence, changing attitudes on related issues rather than the exact issue the minority advocated.

questions.stem: Select all symptoms of groupthink as identified by Janis (1972).

options.text: Illusion of invulnerability leading to excessive optimism and risk-taking
Self-appointed mindguards who shield the group from dissenting information
Systematic evaluation of all available alternatives before deciding
Pressure on dissenters to conform and self-censorship of dissenting opinions
Active solicitation of outside expert opinions to challenge assumptions

questions.explanation: Janis (1972) identified eight symptoms of groupthink: illusion of invulnerability, collective rationalization, belief in inherent morality, stereotyping out-groups, pressure on dissenters, self-censorship, illusion of unanimity, and self-appointed mindguards. Systematic evaluation of alternatives and soliciting outside expert opinions are NOT symptoms of groupthink -- they are actually prevention strategies that Janis recommended to counteract groupthink.

questions.stem: Which of the following conditions have been shown to reduce social loafing in group tasks? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Making individual contributions identifiable within the group
Increasing the personal meaningfulness or importance of the task
Increasing group size to distribute the workload more broadly
Having group members who are friends rather than strangers
Ensuring that individual effort cannot be distinguished from group output

questions.explanation: Social loafing is reduced when individual contributions are identifiable (accountability), the task is personally meaningful or important, groups are small, and group members are friends (increased cohesion). Social loafing is also reduced in collectivist cultures. Increasing group size and making individual effort indistinguishable would increase rather than reduce social loafing, as these conditions are precisely what cause the phenomenon.

questions.stem: Which of the following variations of Milgram's obedience experiment resulted in reduced obedience rates? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: The experimenter gave instructions by telephone rather than in person
Two confederates acting as co-teachers refused to continue
The study was conducted in a prestigious university setting
The learner was placed in the same room as the participant
Two experimenters gave contradictory instructions

questions.explanation: Obedience decreased when: the experimenter was absent (phone instructions, 21% vs. 65%), confederates modeled disobedience (10%), the victim was in the same room (40%), and two experimenters disagreed (0%). Conducting the study at a prestigious university (Yale) was the baseline condition with 65% obedience; moving to an ordinary building reduced obedience to 48%. The university setting actually supported obedience through institutional authority.

questions.stem: A group initially composed of moderately risk-averse investors discusses a potential investment strategy. According to research on group polarization, which outcomes are likely after group discussion? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: The group decision will be more risk-averse than the average pre-discussion individual position
Discussion will expose members to predominantly cautious arguments (persuasive arguments theory)
The group will compromise and reach a moderate middle-ground position
Members may shift to more extreme caution after learning others are also cautious (social comparison)
The group will necessarily shift toward greater risk-taking (risky shift)

questions.explanation: Group polarization predicts that discussion strengthens the average initial tendency of the group. Since this group initially leans cautious, discussion will produce a more cautious decision (not a moderate compromise). Two mechanisms explain this: persuasive arguments theory (members hear predominantly cautious arguments) and social comparison (members discover others are also cautious and shift to be at least as cautious). The risky shift is only one specific case of polarization that occurs when the initial tendency is toward risk, not when it is toward caution.

questions.stem: According to Moscovici's research on minority influence, which factors increase the effectiveness of a consistent minority in changing majority opinions? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: The minority maintains a consistent position over time and across situations
The minority demonstrates flexibility on peripheral issues while maintaining their core position
The minority frequently changes their arguments to appeal to different majority members
The minority is perceived as part of the in-group rather than an out-group
The minority outnumbers the majority in vocal participation during discussions

questions.explanation: Moscovici identified several conditions for effective minority influence: consistency (the single most important factor -- maintaining the same position across time and situations), flexibility (willingness to negotiate on peripheral issues while staying firm on core position), confidence, and identification (being perceived as in-group). Frequently changing arguments undermines the consistency that is essential for minority influence. Simply being vocal does not substitute for consistency and confidence.

questions.stem: Match each group influence phenomenon with the key researcher most closely associated with it.

rows.text: Conformity to majority in line judgments

questions.explanation: Robert Zajonc (1965) proposed the drive theory explanation for social facilitation, arguing that others' presence increases arousal strengthening dominant responses. Irving Janis (1972) introduced the concept of groupthink to explain defective decision-making in cohesive policy groups. Stanley Milgram (1963) conducted the famous obedience studies demonstrating that 65% of participants obeyed to 450V. Solomon Asch (1951, 1956) studied conformity using line judgment tasks, finding 75% of participants conformed at least once.

questions.stem: Match each Tuckman stage of group development with the group therapist behavior that is most appropriate during that stage.

columns.text: Step back and allow the group to function autonomously
Facilitate conflict resolution without suppressing disagreement
Provide structure, set expectations, and reduce member anxiety
Reinforce developing cohesion and emerging group norms

questions.explanation: Tuckman's model has direct implications for group therapy leadership: During forming, the therapist should be more directive, providing structure and reducing anxiety as members orient to the group. During storming, the therapist should facilitate conflict resolution while recognizing that conflict is normal and necessary -- prematurely suppressing disagreement impedes growth. During norming, the therapist reinforces developing cohesion and emerging norms. During performing, the therapist can step back as the group functions effectively and autonomously.

questions.stem: For each group phenomenon, select ALL conditions or factors that contribute to its occurrence.

columns.text: Arousal from others' presence / novel task

questions.explanation: Groupthink is driven by high cohesion and directive leadership (along with insulation from outside opinions and stress). Deindividuation requires anonymity, reduced self-awareness, AND unidentifiable individual contributions -- all reducing personal accountability. Social loafing occurs specifically when individual contributions are unidentifiable (pooled output). Social facilitation impairs performance on novel/complex tasks through arousal from others' presence. Note that deindividuation and social loafing share the factor of unidentifiable individual contributions, but deindividuation additionally requires anonymity and reduced self-awareness.

questions.stem: For each type of social influence, select ALL outcomes that are typically associated with it.
questions.explanation: Normative social influence (conforming to gain approval) produces public compliance without private acceptance. Informational social influence (conforming because the group may be correct) produces genuine private acceptance. Minority influence (Moscovici) produces both genuine private attitude change (conversion) and indirect influence on related attitudes. Obedience to authority (Milgram) involves both public compliance (behavioral compliance) and the agentic state (seeing oneself as an agent of the authority). Milgram participants complied publicly but many experienced significant distress, suggesting they did not privately accept the behavior.

questions.stem: In the Stanford Prison Experiment, Zimbardo randomly assigned participants to be {{blank1}}. Within days, guards became increasingly {{blank2}}, while prisoners became {{blank3}}. The study was terminated after only {{blank4}} due to the deterioration of participants' well-being.

options.text: guards or prisoners in a simulated prison
teachers or learners in a memory experiment
leaders or followers in a mock corporation
therapists or patients in a simulated hospital
democratic and collaborative
authoritarian and abusive
disengaged and apathetic
anxious and indecisive
rebellious and organized in resistance
aggressive and defiant toward authorities
passive and psychologically distressed
cooperative and optimistic about release
6 days of a planned 14-day study
2 days of a planned 30-day study
14 days as originally planned
30 days of a planned 60-day study

questions.explanation: The Stanford Prison Experiment (Zimbardo, 1971) randomly assigned psychologically healthy college students to guard or prisoner roles in a simulated prison. Guards rapidly became authoritarian and abusive, while prisoners became passive and psychologically distressed. The study was terminated after only 6 days of a planned 14-day experiment. Zimbardo concluded that situational forces and social roles powerfully override individual dispositions, illustrating the fundamental attribution error in reverse.

questions.stem: Social facilitation and social loafing produce {{blank1}} effects on performance. Social facilitation occurs when others are present as {{blank2}} and individual performance is evaluable. Social loafing occurs when individual effort is {{blank3}}. The key distinction determining which phenomenon occurs is whether {{blank4}}.

options.text: identical
opposite
unpredictable
negligible
anonymous observers who cannot identify the performer
audience or co-actors who can evaluate the individual
collaborators pooling effort on a shared task
authority figures giving direct instructions
publicly recognized and rewarded
carefully monitored by the group leader
pooled and not individually identifiable
compared to a standardized benchmark
the task is simple versus complex
individual performance can be evaluated or not
the group is large versus small
the individuals know each other personally

questions.explanation: Social facilitation and social loafing produce opposite effects. Social facilitation involves enhanced performance when others are present as audience or co-actors and individual performance is evaluable (evaluation apprehension increases arousal). Social loafing involves reduced effort when individual contributions are pooled and not individually identifiable (diffusion of responsibility). The key distinction is whether individual performance can be evaluated: when it can, facilitation occurs; when it cannot, loafing occurs.

questions.stem: A clinical treatment team at a psychiatric hospital has been together for years and is highly cohesive. The team leader, a senior psychiatrist, typically states her preferred treatment approach first. When a new psychologist joins the team and questions a treatment decision, the senior members dismiss his concerns and privately tell him to 'get with the program.' The team recently made a treatment error that outside consultants attribute to inadequate consideration of alternative approaches.

options.text: High group cohesiveness with insulation from outside perspectives
Directive leadership with the leader stating preferences first
Appropriate hierarchical structure in a medical setting
Normal team development in the storming stage
Groupthink leading to defective decision-making processes
Social loafing by less motivated team members
Group polarization toward risky treatment decisions
Assign a rotating devil's advocate role and invite outside expert consultation
Have the team leader withhold her opinion until others have spoken
Reduce team cohesion by frequently rotating members
Remove the new psychologist who is disrupting team harmony

questions.explanation: This scenario illustrates classic groupthink (Janis). The antecedent conditions include high cohesiveness with insulation from outside opinions and directive leadership (the psychiatrist states preferences first). Symptoms are present: pressure on dissenters, self-censorship, and stereotyping the new member's concerns. Prevention strategies include assigning a devil's advocate, inviting outside experts, and having the leader withhold opinions initially. Removing the dissenting member or reducing cohesion would worsen the problem. The new psychologist may actually be providing the healthy dissent the group needs.

questions.stem: A social psychologist studies an online forum where users post anonymously. She observes that forum members frequently post extremely hostile, racist, and threatening messages -- behaviors they would never exhibit in face-to-face interactions. Users report feeling 'part of the mob' and not individually responsible for the content. The most aggressive posting occurs during late-night threads with high participant counts.

options.text: Anonymity reducing personal identifiability and accountability
Large group size diffusing individual responsibility
Informational social influence from expert forum moderators
Obedience to a direct authority figure giving instructions to post
Deindividuation causing loss of self-awareness and reduced self-regulation
Social facilitation enhancing dominant aggressive responses
Minority influence by a small number of consistent dissenters
Require real-name registration to increase identifiability and self-awareness
Implement visible accountability mechanisms (post history, reputation scores)
Increase the number of anonymous participants to dilute hostility
Provide forums for anonymous venting to allow catharsis

questions.explanation: This scenario illustrates deindividuation in online settings. Contributing factors include anonymity (reducing identifiability) and large group size (diffusing responsibility). These conditions produce a state of reduced self-awareness where normal behavioral restraints weaken. Effective interventions target the root causes: requiring real names increases identifiability, and accountability mechanisms restore self-awareness. Increasing anonymous participants or providing cathartic outlets would worsen the problem -- catharsis has been debunked, and more anonymity intensifies deindividuation.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe research findings on group influence phenomena.
questions.passage: Group influence research has revealed important patterns about human social behavior. [In Asch's conformity studies, approximately 75% of participants conformed at least once, with an overall conformity rate of about 37% across critical trials]. [Social facilitation research shows that the presence of others improves performance on all types of tasks regardless of complexity or familiarity]. [Milgram found that when two confederates acting as co-teachers refused to continue, the obedience rate dropped to approximately 10%]. [Group polarization occurs when group discussion moves members toward a moderate, compromise position between the initial extremes]. [The Stanford Prison Experiment demonstrated that situational forces and social roles can powerfully override individual personality dispositions]. [Social loafing is greater in collectivist cultures because group harmony reduces motivation for individual effort].

highlightableSegments.text: In Asch's conformity studies, approximately 75% of participants conformed at least once, with an overall conformity rate of about 37% across critical trials
Social facilitation research shows that the presence of others improves performance on all types of tasks regardless of complexity or familiarity
Milgram found that when two confederates acting as co-teachers refused to continue, the obedience rate dropped to approximately 10%
Group polarization occurs when group discussion moves members toward a moderate, compromise position between the initial extremes
The Stanford Prison Experiment demonstrated that situational forces and social roles can powerfully override individual personality dispositions
Social loafing is greater in collectivist cultures because group harmony reduces motivation for individual effort

questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, and 5 are accurate. Asch found 75% conformed at least once with 37% overall conformity. Milgram found obedience dropped to 10% when confederates modeled disobedience. The Stanford Prison Experiment demonstrated the power of situations over personality. Statement 2 is wrong because social facilitation IMPAIRS performance on complex/novel tasks (it only improves simple/well-learned tasks). Statement 4 is wrong because group polarization moves groups toward MORE EXTREME positions, not moderate compromise. Statement 6 is wrong because social loafing is actually REDUCED in collectivist cultures where group goals are more salient.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that correctly describe the distinctions between different group influence phenomena.
questions.passage: Understanding the distinctions between group phenomena is essential for the EPPP. [Social facilitation involves enhanced arousal from others' presence strengthening the dominant response, while social loafing involves reduced effort when individual contributions are not identifiable]. [Conformity and obedience are identical processes because both involve changing behavior in response to social pressure]. [Groupthink describes a process of defective decision-making in cohesive groups, while group polarization describes the direction of attitude shift toward the group's initial tendency]. [Normative social influence produces genuine private belief change, while informational social influence produces only public compliance]. [Deindividuation involves loss of self-awareness in group settings leading to impulsive behavior, with anonymity as a key contributing factor]. [In Milgram's studies, the agentic state refers to participants viewing themselves as agents of authority, which reduced their sense of personal responsibility for their actions].

highlightableSegments.text: Social facilitation involves enhanced arousal from others' presence strengthening the dominant response, while social loafing involves reduced effort when individual contributions are not identifiable
Conformity and obedience are identical processes because both involve changing behavior in response to social pressure
Groupthink describes a process of defective decision-making in cohesive groups, while group polarization describes the direction of attitude shift toward the group's initial tendency
Normative social influence produces genuine private belief change, while informational social influence produces only public compliance
Deindividuation involves loss of self-awareness in group settings leading to impulsive behavior, with anonymity as a key contributing factor
In Milgram's studies, the agentic state refers to participants viewing themselves as agents of authority, which reduced their sense of personal responsibility for their actions

questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, 5, and 6 are correct. Social facilitation and loafing are contrasting phenomena based on arousal vs. diffusion of responsibility. Groupthink is a process while polarization is a directional shift. Deindividuation involves loss of self-awareness with anonymity as key. The agentic state reduces personal responsibility in obedience. Statement 2 is wrong because conformity (peer pressure) and obedience (authority commands) are distinct processes. Statement 4 has the definitions reversed: NORMATIVE influence produces public compliance, and INFORMATIONAL influence produces genuine private belief change.

questions.stem: Arrange Tuckman's stages of group development in the correct sequential order from initial formation to termination.

items.text: Forming: Orientation, dependence on leader, testing boundaries
Storming: Conflict, power struggles, resistance to group influence
Norming: Cohesion develops, norms established, roles clarified
Performing: Functional teamwork, flexible problem-solving, productivity
Adjourning: Termination, disengagement, possible grief over ending
Reforming: Group reconvenes with modified membership and renewed purpose

questions.explanation: Tuckman's (1965) original model proposed four stages: Forming (orientation, dependence), Storming (conflict, power struggles), Norming (cohesion, norm development), and Performing (productive collaboration). Tuckman and Jensen (1977) later added Adjourning (termination, closure). The reforming stage represents an extension where groups may reconvene with modified membership. The key clinical insight is that storming (conflict) is a necessary developmental phase -- attempting to skip it typically results in superficial group cohesion.

questions.stem: Arrange the following Milgram obedience experiment variations in order from highest to lowest obedience rates.

items.text: Baseline: Separate rooms, experimenter present in person (65%)
Ordinary building: Not at Yale University (48%)
Learner in same room as participant (40%)
Participant must touch learner to administer shock (30%)
Experimenter gives instructions by phone, not present (21%)
Two confederate co-teachers refuse to continue (10%)

questions.explanation: Milgram's variations systematically identified factors affecting obedience: The baseline (65%) had maximum authority presence and minimum victim proximity. Obedience decreased with reduced institutional authority (ordinary building, 48%), increased victim proximity (same room 40%, touching 30%), reduced authority presence (phone instructions, 21%), and social support for disobedience (confederates rebel, 10%). Two experimenters disagreeing produced 0% obedience. The pattern reveals that obedience is highest when authority is close and legitimate, the victim is distant, and no one models disobedience.

questions.stem: A researcher measures individual performance on a rope-pulling task under two conditions: alone and in groups of increasing size. The graph shows average individual force exerted (in kg) as a function of group size.
questions.question: Which interpretation best explains the discrepancy between actual and expected individual force?

options.text: Social facilitation impairs performance on the complex task of rope pulling
Social loafing increases with group size as individual contributions become less identifiable
Group polarization shifts members toward reduced effort as a group norm
Deindividuation causes members to lose awareness of their physical capabilities

questions.explanation: This pattern replicates Ringelmann's (1913) classic finding: individual effort decreases as group size increases because individual contributions become less identifiable -- the defining feature of social loafing. The steady decline with increasing group size demonstrates that when individual effort is pooled, people exert less effort than when working alone. This is not social facilitation (rope pulling is a simple task that would be facilitated, not impaired, by audience presence). It is not group polarization or deindividuation, which involve different mechanisms.

questions.stem: A researcher tracks attitude ratings (1-10 scale, where 10 = most favorable) of a jury panel before and after deliberation. Six jurors initially lean toward guilty (average favorability toward conviction = 7.2) and deliberate for 4 hours.
questions.question: Which group phenomenon best explains this pattern of attitude change during deliberation?

options.text: Groupthink, as the jury suppressed dissenting opinions to maintain harmony
Group polarization, as deliberation strengthened the jury's initial tendency toward conviction
Social loafing, as some jurors reduced their cognitive effort during deliberation
Normative influence, as jurors conformed publicly without changing their private attitudes

questions.explanation: This pattern illustrates group polarization: the jury initially leaned toward conviction (7.2/10), and deliberation progressively strengthened this tendency to an extreme position (9.1/10). Group polarization occurs through persuasive arguments (hearing additional pro-conviction arguments) and social comparison (discovering others also favor conviction and shifting to match or exceed them). While groupthink involves defective decision-making, it specifically requires high cohesion and directive leadership, which are not described here. The steady progressive shift is characteristic of polarization rather than the sudden conformity of groupthink.

questions.stem: Categorize each factor according to whether it increases conformity, decreases conformity, or has been shown to have no reliable effect on conformity in Asch-type experiments.

items.text: Unanimous group agreement (no dissenters)
A single ally who gives the correct answer
Increasing group size from 5 to 15 members
Greater ambiguity of the task (harder judgments)
Allowing responses to be made privately (in writing)
Higher cohesiveness of the group

questions.explanation: Conformity increases with unanimity, task ambiguity (informational influence is stronger), and group cohesiveness (normative influence is stronger). Conformity decreases when a dissenter/ally breaks unanimity (even giving a different wrong answer helps) and when responses are private rather than public. Group size increases conformity up to about 3-5 members but then plateaus, so increasing from 5 to 15 has no reliable additional effect. These factors are critical for understanding the mechanisms underlying conformity.

questions.stem: Categorize each scenario as primarily illustrating social facilitation, social loafing, or deindividuation.

items.text: An experienced runner posts a personal best time during a race with spectators cheering
Group project members contribute less effort when only a single group grade is assigned
Fans at a concert wearing matching costumes engage in uncharacteristic destructive behavior
A novice pianist makes more errors during a recital than during private practice
Anonymous online users post extreme and offensive comments they would never say in person
Team members exert less effort during a tug-of-war when they believe their individual pull is not measured

questions.explanation: Social facilitation is illustrated by the runner (well-practiced task enhanced by audience) and the novice pianist (novel task impaired by audience) -- both involve arousal from others' presence affecting dominant responses. Social loafing occurs in the group project (single group grade makes individual effort unidentifiable) and the tug-of-war (individual pull not measured). Deindividuation is shown by concert fans (anonymity through costumes, group arousal) and online users (anonymity leading to norm-violating behavior). The key distinctions are: facilitation involves evaluable individual performance, loafing involves pooled unidentifiable effort, and deindividuation involves loss of self-awareness through anonymity.
